p: The high sensitivity of all of the tested strains to the essential oil of O. vulgare is of particular interest. This antimicrobial effect could be attributed to an alteration in the lipidic components of the bacterial plasma membrane, resulting in the leakage of intracellular contents [ 44]. Furthermore, O. vulgare essential oil’s higher antimicrobial activity could be explained by the amount of phenolic oxygenated monoterpenes—especially thymol, p-cymene, and carvacrol, which were found in the ratio of 27.6% and they could show a synergistic effect causing membrane destabilization. Some studies ensure that the combination of carvacrol and thymol at low concentrations could be used as a reference to apply this combination in foods to control S. aureus, to maintain the organoleptic properties, and to extend the shelf-life of them [ 45]. Other studies have reported the synergic potential of oregano essential oil to preserve food, such as salmon and seaweed burgers [ 18], beef meatballs [ 46], fish and meat products [ 19]. In this context, the activity found in essential oil from the arid Andean region revealed its potential as a food additive to combat common foodborne pathogens.
